Award.AwardTitle: New GK-12: BE-LA: Body Engineering Los Angeles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI Name: Krishna Nayak
Institution Name: University of Southern California
Proposal Title: BE-LA: Body Engineering Los Angeles
Proposal ID: 1045595

This project will establish a new GK-12 program at USC that will develop graduate fellows majoring in engineering and related disciplines into well-rounded STEM leaders of tomorrow, while introducing cutting-edge body engineering research into urban Los Angeles middle school science classrooms. Graduate fellows will be provided with training and practice in education, communication, leadership, collaboration, and cultural sensitivity that enhances their doctoral training. Each graduate fellow will be paired with a middle school science teacher, and will serve as an in-class science resource throughout the school year. Fellows will develop and deliver original lesson plans incorporating their doctoral research and the research of their faculty advisors. Topics will include: non-invasive sensing and imaging, speech articulation, hand articulation, neuromuscular control, vision and recognition, cardiovascular mechanics, nutrition and metabolism, biological and bio-compatible materials, and human-machine interaction. The intellectual merit of this project includes 1) the research theme of body engineering, which is a strength of USC, and provides an engaging vehicle for demonstrating scientific and engineering principles and introducing university research into K-12 classrooms; and 2) the development and use of powerful pedagogical structures that will help graduate fellows communicate their research to middle school students.

The broader significance of this project includes 1) development of a cadre of graduate fellows that possess the communication, leadership, and collaboration skills, and cultural sensitivity required to become STEM leaders; and 2) development of skills and interest in students at a critical stage for STEM learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Body Engineering Los Angeles (BE-LA) GK-12 Program at the University of Southern California’s Viterbi School of Engineering brings cutting edge research and knowledge in the science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) fields to public school students in the Los Angeles area. The program’s main goals are to build graduate fellows’ skills in communication, teaching, leadership, collaboration and promote cultural sensitivity while exposing students to science and engineering role models and enhancing the STEM classroom curriculum. Graduate fellows used the concept of body engineering as a way to introduce STEM research to middle school students.

The BE-LA GK-12 Program focuses on partnering primarily with public middle schools that are within a five mile radius of the campus. Research shows that the middle school years, between sixth grade and eighth grade, are critical for developing skills and interest in STEM long-term. BE-LA Program’s target region includes areas where school academic reports show low proficiency in math and science on state standardized tests. Additionally, student demographic information shows that over 90 percent of students identify with racial or ethnic populations that are underrepresented in college and the STEM fields and more than 85 percent of students qualified for the National School Lunch Program to receive free or reduced lunches.  

From 2011 to 2016, the BE-LA program supported twenty-nine graduate fellows. The fellows conducted PhD level research from many STEM disciplines including Electrical Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, Computer Science, Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Civil Engineering, Neuroscience and Civil Engineering. While conducting research, fellows had the unique opportunity to spend one academic year as a resident scientist or engineer in a public school classroom and partner with a teacher to plan and implement lessons relating to STEM topics. Each fellow spent two or three days per week on average in their classrooms. Fellows presented their research, led hands-on activities and lab experiments, shared about the college experience, and invited other fellows and colleagues to speak about their research and careers. Fellows also organized visits to the USC campus for their students. The students had the opportunity to see fellows’ research first-hand, tour the campus, and some visited the proximally located California Science Center, home to the Endeavor Space Shuttle.

Over the five years, the BE-LA program partnered with 20 teachers from 12 schools and reached nearly 5000 students through its school partnerships and outreach events. The feedback from outreach events were overwhelmingly positive as the program was invited back year after year and asked to increase our event schedule. Overall, our results showed positive gains in fellows skills in communication, teaching, and leadership. Teachers reported their own improvements in content knowledge and high levels of engagement among students due to the presence of a fellow in the classroom. Results also showed increases in student interest and confidence in studying and doing STEM projects.
